facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 69 of 1964 was filed by special leave from the judgment dated October 10, 1961 of Andhra Pradesh High Court in Second Appeal No. 872 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 69 of 1964. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated October 10, 1961, of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Second Appeal No. 872 of 1958.

facts.text: Government of Madras issued a licence on November 22, 1927 to Bezwada Vijayawada Municipal Council under s. 3 of Indian Electricity Act, 1910 for supply of electric energy within municipal limits at rates not exceeding maximum in third annexure.

anchor.surface_text: On November 22, 1927, the Government of Madras, in exercise of its powers under s. 3 1  of the Indian Electricity Act, 1910  IX of 1910 , hereinafter called the Act, issued a licence to the Bezwada  number Vijayawada  Municipal Council for the supply of electric energy within the municipal limits of Bezwada at rates number exceeding the maximum charges given in the third annexure to the said licence.

facts.text: Appellants are consumers of electric energy for domestic and industrial purposes who entered into agreements with the licensee agreeing to pay the current official scale of rates.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants, who are some of the companysumers of electric energy for domestic and industrial purposes, entered into agreements with the licensee for the supply of electric energy to them for domestic, industrial and other purposes, agreeing to pay the current official scale of rates.

facts.text: On December 13, 1940, the Municipality passed a resolution bringing into force new rates for supply of electric energy from April 1, 1940.

anchor.surface_text: On December 13, 1940, the Municipality passed a resolution bringing into force new rates for the supply of electric energy from April 1, 1940.

facts.text: Consumers paid the rates fixed by the 1940 resolution till the year 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The companysumers paid the rates so fixed till the year 1956.

facts.text: On April 30, 1956, the Municipal Council passed a resolution enhancing the rates from 1-4-1956.

anchor.surface_text: On April 30, 1956, the Municipal Council passed another resolution enhancing the rates from 1-4-1956.

facts.text: Appellants filed a representative suit against Vijayawada Municipality in District Munsif Court, Vijayawada for declaration that April 30, 1956 resolution was illegal and for injunction.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants filed a representative suit against the Vijayawada Municipality in the Court of the District Munsif, Vijayawada, for a declaration that the said resolution dated April 30, 1956, passed by the Municipal Council was illegal, invalid and unenforceable and for an injunction restraining the said Municipality from companylecting charges from the companysumers of electric energy in the licensees area at the new revised rates in pursuance of the impugned resolution.

facts.text: District Munsif held demand of enhanced rate legal and valid and dismissed the suit.

anchor.surface_text: The learned District Munsif held that the demand of enhanced rate was legal and valid and dismissed the suit.

facts.text: On appeal, Subordinate Judge held levy from date of resolution good but no retrospective operation and claim for duty at half an anna per unit invalid; modified decree.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal, the learned Subordinate Judge held that the levy from the date of the said resolution was good, but it companyld number be given retrospective operation. He further held that the claim for duty at half an anna per unit was invalid. In the result he modified the decree of the District Munsif.

facts.text: Division Bench of Andhra Pradesh High Court confirmed decree of Subordinate Judge on October 10, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: On a further appeal, a Division Bench of the Andhra Pradesh High Court companyfirmed the decree of the Subordinate Judge. By special leave the present appeal has been filed in this Court.

facts.text: Ex. B-4 is an agreement dated May 27, 1932 between Municipality and one of the appellants.

anchor.surface_text: Ex. B-4 is one such agreement dated May 27, 1932, between the Municipality and one of the appellants herein.

facts.text: Agreement para IV: Consumer shall pay at rates in licensees Current Official Scale of rates.

anchor.surface_text: Para, IV. The companysumer shall pay to the licensee for all electrical energy so supplied at the rates and in accordance with the terms, given in the licensees Current Official Scale of rates and the signing of this Agreement is held to imply companycurrence in the terms of the said Scales of rates.

facts.text: Agreement para X: Subject to Bezwada Municipal Electric Licence 1927 and Indian Electricity Act 1910.

anchor.surface_text: Para, X. This Agreement shall be read and companystrued as subject in all respects to the provisions of the Bezwada Municipal Electric Licence, 1927, and to the provisions of the Indian Electricity Act 1910, and of any modification or re-enactment thereof for the time being in force thereunder so far as the same respectively may be applicable.

facts.text: On April 1, 1940, Electricity Department of Vijayawada Municipality prepared Conditions and Rates of Supply.

anchor.surface_text: On April 1, 1940, the Electricity Department of the Vijayawada Municipality prepared a document styled as Conditions and Rates of Supply.

facts.text: Petitioner contention: Rates agreed cannot be unilaterally altered by Municipality.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. A.V. Viswanatha Sastri, learned companynsel for the appellants raised before us the following two companytentions The rates agreed upon between the companysumers and the Municipality cannot be unilaterally altered and increased by the Municipality to the prejudice of the companysumers and, therefore, the said resolution dated April 30, 1956, was invalid and unenforceable

facts.text: Petitioner contention: Resolution passed without previous sanction of State Government under s.21(2) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: and  2  as the said resolution was passed without obtaining the previous sanction of the State Government under s. 21 2  of the Act, it was void for that reason also.

facts.text: No previous sanction of State Government obtained for the April 30, 1956 resolution.

anchor.surface_text: as admittedly the sanction of the State Government was number obtained before such alteration

facts.text: Court held that under para IV of agreement, consumers agreed to pay official scale of rates current from time to time.

anchor.surface_text: We have. therefore, on a reasonable companystruction of the ambiguous expression current having regard to the entire document and the surrounding circumstances, companye to the companyclusion that the words current official scale of rates in para. IV of the agreement mean the official scale of rates current or prevalent from time to time during the currency of the agreement.

facts.text: Court held no sanction under s.21(2) necessary as no alteration of condition in agreement.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, numbersanction of the State Government was necessary for enhancing the rates.

facts.text: Government increased the licence fee in the present case.

anchor.surface_text: for the Government may increase the licence fee, as it has done in the present case,

issues.text: Whether the words 'current official scale of rates' in para. IV of the agreement relate to the scale of rates current on the date when the agreement was entered into or to the scale of rates current from time to time

anchor.surface_text: The conflicting arguments centre on the question whether the words current official scale of rates in para. IV relate to the scale of rates current on the date when the agreement was entered into or refer to the scale of rates current from time to time in accordance

issues.answer: rates current from time to time

issues.text: Whether the resolution dated April 30, 1956 was void as passed without previous sanction of the State Government under s. 21(2) of the Act

anchor.surface_text: and  2  as the said resolution was passed without obtaining the previous sanction of the State Government under s. 21 2  of the Act, it was void for that reason also.

issues.text: Whether s. 21(2) of the Act is a general provision and s. 23 a specific provision in regard to fixing of rates such that s. 23 prevails over s. 21(2)

arguments.claim: The rates agreed upon between the consumers and the Municipality cannot be unilaterally altered and increased by the Municipality to the prejudice of the consumers and, therefore, the said resolution dated April 30, 1956, was invalid and unenforceable

anchor.surface_text: Mr. A.V. Viswanatha Sastri, learned counsel for the appellants raised before us the following two contentions The rates agreed upon between the consumers and the Municipality cannot be unilaterally altered and increased by the Municipality to the prejudice of the consumers

arguments.court_reasoning: Interpreted 'current official scale of rates' in para IV as meaning rates current from time to time, based on whole document, surrounding circumstances, ss 22-23 non-discrimination, and policy considerations

arguments.claim: The resolution was passed without obtaining the previous sanction of the State Government under s. 21(2) of the Act, it was void for that reason also

arguments.court_reasoning: Enhancing rates was not an alteration of any condition in the agreement but in terms of para IV; no change in condition requiring sanction under s 21(2)

arguments.claim: s. 21(2) of the Act was a general provision relating to conditions, whereas s. 23 thereof was a specific provision in regard to fixing of rates and that s. 23 would prevail over s. 21
On the interpretation of para. IV of the agreement suggested by the respondents there was no alteration in the conditions at all and, therefore, there was no scope for invoking s. 21 of the Act

court_response_anchor.surface_text: Mr. Tatachari, while supporting this argument, added that on the interpretation of para. IV of the agreement suggested by the respondents there was nu

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed no alteration of condition per para IV interpretation

arguments.claim: The words 'current official scale of rates' in para. IV of the agreement mean the official scale of rates current or prevalent from time to time during the currency of the agreement

anchor.surface_text: We have. therefore, on a reasonable construction of the ambiguous expression current having regard to the entire document and the surrounding circumstances, come to the conclusion that the words current official scale of rates in para. IV of the agreement mean the official scale of rates current or prevalent from time to time during the currency of the agreement.

arguments.claim: Under ss 22 and 23, licensee cannot discriminate in rates; fixed rates at agreement date would cause discrimination if rates change later

anchor.surface_text: When an application is filed an obligation is imposed under s.22 of the Act on the licensee to supply energy... Section 23 of the Act says that a licensee shall not, in making any agreement for the supply of energy, show undue preference to any person.

arguments.claim: Public body like Municipality cannot agree to fixed rates risking loss due to govt licence fee increase or cost rise; flexible term needed

anchor.surface_text: for the Government may increase the licence fee, as it has done in the present case, or there may be a rise in the cost of distribution.

arguments.claim: Enhancing rates under para IV does not alter any condition requiring sanction under s 21(2); change in terms of the condition

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, no sanction of the State Government was necessary for enhancing the rates.

holdings.text: We have therefore, on a reasonable construction of the ambiguous expression current having regard to the entire document and the surrounding circumstances, come to the conclusion that the words current official scale of rates in para. IV of the agreement mean the official scale of rates current or prevalent from time to time during the currency of the agreement.

anchor.surface_text: We have. therefore, on a reasonable construction of the ambiguous expression current having regard to the entire document and the surrounding circumstances, come to the conclusion that the words current official scale of

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ambiguous term 'current' interpreted using entire agreement (paras IV, V, X), administrative practices, statutory non-discrimination under ss 22-23, policy needs of public utility to adjust rates for costs/licence fees without loss or discrimination.

holdings.text: If the said term was a condition within the meaning of s. 21(2) of the Act, there was no change at all in that condition, for the change in the rates was not in derogation of the condition but in terms of it... Therefore, no sanction of the State Government was necessary for enhancing the rates.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, no sanction of the State Government was necessary for enhancing the rates.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agreement para IV already obligated payment at rates fixed from time to time; enhancement implements existing condition without alteration, so s.21(2) sanction not triggered.

outcome.relief_summary: Resolution dated April 30, 1956 held valid; appellants contractually liable to pay enhanced rates; no State Government sanction required under s.21(2) of the Act
